document.docTitle: Saponins of Agave: Chemistry and bioactivity

mods:titleInfo.mods:title: Saponins of Agave: Chemistry and bioactivity

subSection.paragraph: Review

paragraph.docTitle:
Saponins of
Agave
: Chemistry and bioactivity

paragraph.emphasis: Natural Product Chemistry and Process Development Division, CSIR-Institute of Himalayan Bioresource Technology, Palampur, 176 061, Himachal Pradesh , India
A R T I C L E I N F o

subSection.paragraph: Received 27 February 2016 Received in revised form
Accepted 23 June 2016 Available online 30 June 2016
Saponins
Sapogenins
Spirostanol glycosides Furostanol glycosides

paragraph.emphasis: A B S T R A C T

subSection.paragraph:
The genus
Agave
comprises more than 400 species with geographical presence in the tropical and sub-tropical regions of the world. These plants have a rich history of folkloric use and are known for a wide spectrum of applications. Secondary metabolites of diverse chemical classes have been reported from
Agave species.
Owing to their pharmacological significance, the steroidal saponins of
Agave
have caught the attention of phytochemists, biologists and drug discovery scientists. The present review describes 141 steroidal saponins and sapogenins and covers the literature published from 1970 to 2015. It is a comprehensive and coherent presentation of the structures, methods of chemical profiling, structure elucidation and biological activities of the saponins and sapogenins reported from
Agave
. The article provides a perspective of the research on steroidal compounds of
Agave
.
© 2016 Elsevier Ltd. All rights reserved.

The genus
Agave
belongs to the family Agavaceae and is distributed throughout tropical and sub-tropical regions of the world. This genus has more than 400 species growing in arid and semi-arid climates. Agaves are often referred to as ‘hardy century plant,’ ‘rough century plant’ or ‘wild century plant’ in recognition of their ability to grow in dry lands. The name ‘century plant’ implies a vast array of uses and applications of Agaves ( Hackman et al., 2006 ). Human interest in the genus
Agave
extends back to an ancient era when agua miel , a fermented beverage, was extracted from these plants.
Agave plants
have been used as a source of fiber, food and beverages ( Hackman et al., 2006 ; Nava-Cruz et al., 2014 ; Santos-Zea et al., 2012 ). More recently,
Agave species
have also been investigated for their potential as nutraceuticals, prebiotics, natural sweeteners and biofuels ( Garcia-Vieyra et al., 2014 ; Mellado-Mojica and Lopez, 2015 ; Nava-Cruz et al., 2014 ; Xiong et al., 2014 ; Stewart, 2015 ).

The earliest report of the saponins of
Agave
was in the year 1932 ( Jones et al., 1932 ). Furthermore,
Agave
was recognized as a new and potential source of steroidal sapogenins ( Marker et al., 1943 , 1947 ). Till now, more than 50 species of
Agave
have been investigated for their saponin and sapogenin constituents. An earlier review gave an overview of the phytochemistry of Agavaceae family ( Simmons-Boyce and Tinto, 2007 ). It included some of the sapogenins and saponins of
Agave
,
Cordyline
,
Dracaena
,
Furcraea
,
Nolina
,
Sansevieria
and
Yucca
. However, it did not discuss the extraction, isolation, chemical profiling and structure elucidation of these compounds. Another review on the traditional products of
Agave species
focused on food and nutraceutical products of
Agave
and medicinal properties of the extracts and compounds isolated from this genus ( Santos-Zea et al., 2012 ). Almaraz-Abarca et al. (2013) recently reviewed the phenols of
Agave
and compiled details of occurrence of phenols and flavonoids in the different species of
Agave
, as well as the intra- and inter-specific variability in the phenolic profiles and chemotaxonomic importance of the phenolics in this genus ( Almaraz-Abarca et al., 2013 ).

Saponins are glycosides of triterpenes or steroids with a number of bioactivities like anticancer, adjuvant, immunostimulant, antiinflammatory, antimicrobial, hypocholesterolemic and antioxidant properties ( Güçlü-Ustündăg, and Mazza, 2007 ; Lacaille-Dubois and Wagner, 1996 ). Saponins are receiving much attention from chemists and biologists globally for new drug discovery ( Elekofehinti, 2015 ; Güçlü-Ustündag ̆and Mazza, 2007 ; Lacaille-Dubois and Wagner, 1996 ; Mahato and Garai, 1998 ; Podolak et al., 2010 ; Sparg et al., 2004 ; Thakur et al., 2011 ). There have also been substantial developments in the phytochemistry and bioactivity studies of saponins of
Agave
in the last two decades. The present review is a comprehensive description of the sapogenins and saponins reported from
Agave species
, their structural peculiarities, methods of extraction, isolation and chemical profiling, spectroscopic properties and biological activities. The literature has been searched using Scifinder ® and the articles published 1970 onwards have been reviewed. The aim of this review is to provide a perspective of the research on steroidal sapogenins and saponins of
Agave
.

subSection.paragraph:
Agave
is an important source of steroidal sapogenins of the spirostanol-type (
1 — 27
) whereas Agavegenin D ( 28 ) is the only cholestane-type sapogenin reported from
Agave
. Sapogenins with furostanol and furospirostanol skeleta have not been discovered in this genus yet. Spirostanols are biogenetically derived from cholestane and are 16,22; 22,26-bisepoxycholestanes ( Agrawal et al., 1995 ). The spirostanol skeleton has a tetrahydrofuran ring (E) and a tetrahydropyran ring (F) joined at C- 22 in a spiran fashion. These compounds are isolated from leaves, flowers, leaf juice, rhizomes and callus cultures of
Agave plants
. Spirostan sapogenins of
Agave
differ from each other in terms of a) the configuration and number of the hydroxyl moieties attached to the parent nucleus, b) presence or absence of carbonyl group at C-12, c) presence or absence of unsaturation in rings B or C and d) configuration of H at C-5 and -25 (due to biogenetic differences) (Agrawal et al., 1985, 1995). Table 1 and Fig. 1 present the sapogenins reported from the genus
Agave
.

A saponin molecule is typically comprised of an aglycone (hydrophobic, sapogenin) and a sugar (hydrophilic, glycone) unit. Sugar moieties present in the
Agave
saponins include b -D-glucopyranosyl, b -D-galactopyranosyl, b -D-xylopyranosyl and
a -
Lrhamnopyranosyls moieties. On the basis of the sapogenin nucleus present, saponins of
Agave
can be broadly classified as spirostanol glycosides and furostanol glycosides (Agrawal et al., 1985, 1995). These compounds, depending on the number of sugars attached, may further be classified as mono-, di-, tri-, tetra-, penta- or hexaglycosides. If the sugar (or sugar chain) is present at only one position of the sapogenin, the saponin is called monodesmosidic ( Agrawal et al., 1995 ). The majority of spirostanol saponins of
Agave
is monodesmosidic and have sugar unit present at C-3 of the aglycone ( Table 2 ). Bidesmosidic saponins, on the other hand, have two sugar units located at two different points of the aglycone nucleus ( Agrawal et al., 1995 ). Bidesmosidic spirostanol saponins are relatively scarce in
Agave plants
, with only a few being reported till date. However, a good number of bidesmosidic furostanol glycosides are found in this genus ( Table 3 ). The forthcoming subsections discuss the structure, occurrence, chemistry and bioactivities of the spirostanol and furostanol glycosides of
Agave
.

The majority of the spirostanol glycosides reported from
Agave
have trans , trans and cis geometry for B/C, C/D and D/E rings, respectively. However, rings A/B can either be trans or cis fused leading to either an a - or b -hydrogen at position 5. The 21-methyl group is a -oriented and the spiro -carbon atom (C-22) is present in its R configuration. The 27-methyl group can either be equatorial ( a ) or axial ( b ) leading to 25 R or 25 S -configurations, respectively.

In spirostanol monoglycosides (
29 — 35
), the b -D-glucopyranoside is the sugar moiety present in most cases. Compounds 31 , 32 and 35 have a free 3-hydroxyl moiety and the sugar is attached through a 6-hydroxyl group in 31 and 32 and through a 24- hydroxyl in 35 ( Fig. 2 ). Monodesmosidic spirostanol diglycosides (
43 — 50
) have b -D-galactopyranoside as the inner monosaccharide and a - or b -D-glucopyranoside as the terminal monosaccharide. However, bidesmosidic spirostanol diglycosides (
37 — 42
) invariably possess b -D-glucopyranoside as their sugar moieties. Compounds
37 — 41
have glycosylated hydroxyl groups at positions 3 and 6. In 42 , both 6- and 24-hydroxyls are glycosylated, while the 3-hydroxyl moiety is free. It is notable that glycosylation at positions other than 3 are only observed in the case of mono- and di-glycosides of sapogenins. Structures of spirostanol glycosides are presented in
Figs. 3 — 7
. Table 2 also gives the occurrence and bioactivities of spirostanol glycosides reported from
Agave
.

Furostanol glycosides are 16,22-epoxycholestane derivatives and have a pentacyclic skeleton. Most of the furostanol saponins of
Agave
are bidesmosidic and are 3- and 26- O -glycosides ( Fig. 8 ). The monosaccharide present at the position 26 is invariably b -D-glucopyranoside. Compounds 118 and 119 are tridesmosidic and are glycosylated at C-3, -6 and -26.

Furostanol glycosides of
Agave
can be categorized as 22-hydroxy or 22-methoxy furostanols. The latter are artifacts generated from the former as a result of extraction and processing of the plant materials with methanol ( Agrawal et al., 1995 ; Yokosuka et al., 2009). These compounds, on treatment with b -glucosidase, give the corresponding spirostanol saponins and b -D-glucose (Yokosuka et al., 2009; Yokosuka and Mimaki, 2009 ). Compound 118 , for example, gives 36 after enzymatic hydrolysis ( Yokosuka and Mimaki, 2007 ). Table 3 gives the details of furostanol glycosides of
Agave
.

subSection.paragraph:
Hecogenin ( 1 ) is reported from several species of
Agave
and is an important precursor in the chemical synthesis of steroid hormones ( Quintans et al., 2014 ). It is one of the most economically-important sapogenins reported from this genus. Therefore, several technologies have been developed over the years for fast and convenient isolation of hecogenin ( 1 ) from
Agave plants
. It has also been isolated from sisal waste (
Agave sisalana
leaves, after removal of fibers) in five simple steps. Sisal waste is refluxed (100 ǫC ) with distilled water for 3 h to obtain a crude sisal waste extract. This extract is then suspended in ethanol-water (8:2) and polysaccharides are precipitated out. The enriched extract is concentrated and partitioned with ethyl acetate. The organic layer is concentrated and subsequently hydrolyzed in the presence of hydrochloric acid/ ethanol. The hydrolyzed reaction mixture is neutralized using sodium hydroxide and again extracted with ethyl acetate. The ethyl acetate layer is dried to obtain pure hecogenin ( 1 ) with a yield of 460 mg /kg of sisal waste ( Santos and Branco, 2014 ).

Saponins and sapogenins are analyzed in natural matrices viz. leaves, leaf juice, coffee grounds (sapogenin concentrates) and callus cultures of plants using different methodologies. Some of these methods are TLC, high-performance thin layer chromatography (HPTLC), gas (liquid) chromatography (GLC or GC) and HPLC.

subSection.paragraph:
Ghoghari and Rajani (2006) have developed an HPTLC method for the determination of hecogenin ( 1 ) in the leaf powder of
Agave americana
. The mobile phase used for the analysis was toluene/ ethyl acetate/methanol (6:1:0.8). Derivatization of the analytes was done with anisaldehyde-sulfuric acid reagent followed by heating of the TLC plate for 3 min at 100 ǫC . The yellow band corresponding to hecogenin ( 1 ) was densitometrically quantified at 430 nm . This simple, sensitive and accurate method can be routinely used for quality control of
A. americana
plant material ( Ghoghari and Rajani, 2006 ). Similar research reported the simultaneous quantitation of hecogenin ( 1 ), kammogenin ( 8 ) and manogenin ( 4 ) in the extracts of
Agave amaniensis ( Indrayanto et al., 1994 )
.

subSection.paragraph:
Structure elucidation of saponins involve determination of both units present in the structure viz. the sapogenin and the sugar moiety ( Agrawal et al., 1995 ). The number of sapogenin nuclei reported from
Agave
is limited, and identification involves trivial techniques such as co-TLC with reference standards and comparison of spectroscopic data with literature values. However, as the number of sugar units and branching points increase, structure elucidation becomes increasingly difficult. Hence, the use of chemical methods as well as advanced spectral techniques for complete and unambiguous structure elucidation are required ( Plock et al., 2001 ).

Sapogenins may be readily identified on the basis of their TLC, IR, MS, 1 H and 13 C NMR data. A careful comparison of the spectroscopic data of sapogenins with literature reports can lead to unambiguous identification of them ( Plock et al., 2001 ). However, in cases where a detailed analysis of the structure is required, 1D and 2D NMR techniques are needed ( Fig. S1 ).

The spiroketal moiety of the spirostanol sapogenins and saponins is readily characterized by IR absorptions at 980, 915, 898 and 862 cm –1 . If the 898 cm –1 band is intense, as compared to the 915 cm –1 band, it indicates a R -configuration of the 25-methyl group. The absorption band near 1700 cm –1 also indicates the presence of a keto functionality, and hydroxyl groups have absorption bands near 3420 and 1046 cm –1 ( Blunden et al., 1980a ).

Different types of mass spectroscopic experiments have been used in the recent past for the structure elucidation of saponins, with the most common being High Resolution Mass Spectrometry (HRMS). Electron Spray Ionization (ESI) with time-of-flight (TOF) detection and Fast Atom Bombardment (FAB) are the commonly used ionization techniques. Both negative as well as positive ion modes have been used to obtain the molecular weight of saponins.

Hecogenin ( 1 ) has a molecular ion peak at m/z 430. Its base peak at m/z 139 is characteristic of the spiroketal moiety present in the structure. Fig. S2 shows generation of the base peak ion from the molecular ion of hecogenin ( 1 ). Other significant fragment ions are also present. Saturated monohydroxyspirostanes, such as tigogenin ( 13 , M þ at m/z 416), has prominent fragments at m/z 347, 302, 287, 273 and 139 ( El-Hashash et al., 1995 ). The mass spectrum (MS) of saturated dihydroxyspirostanes with hydroxyl groups located on rings A, B or C as in ruizgenin ( 19 , M þ at m/z 432) also have significant fragment ions at m/z 318, 303, 300, 289, 285, 271 and 139. Similarly, MS of the monounsaturated dihydroxyspirostane type of sapogenins (yuccagenin, 24 , M þ at m/z 430) have fragment ions at m/z 316, 301, 298, 287, 283, 269 and 139 ( Blunden et al., 1980a ; Quilez et al., 2004 ).

Most of the saponins of
Agave
have four methyl resonances in the 1 H and 13 C NMR spectra. These signals may be distinguished into two tertiary ( CH 3 -18 and –19) and two secondary methyls ( CH 3 -21 and –27) in most cases. The tertiary methyls are always b - oriented and are present at the ring junctions of C/D and A/B, respectively. The 21-methyl group is a -oriented and establishes a S - configuration for C-20. Compound 40 , however, is an exception to this general observation as the presence of a b -hydroxyl at C-20 renders the CH 3 -21 moiety tertiary and an R -configuration for C-20 ( Yokosuka and Mimaki, 2007 ). The 27-methyl group may either be a - or b -oriented leading to R- or S- stereochemistries at C-25.

Fig. 8. Structures of furostanol saponins of the genus

.

subSection.paragraph: The chemical shift of C-22 indicates the type of parent skeleton, i.e., spirostanol or furostanol. In the case of spirostanol glycosides, C-22 resonates between d 108.6 to 109.8 with the chemical shift not being affected by the presence of a 12-carbonyl, a Δ 9(11) unsaturation, hydroxyl moieties in rings A, B or C and the configuration at C-25. A hydroxyl unit at C-20, however, leads to an upfield shift (2 — 3 ppm) in C-22 ( Yokosuka and Mimaki, 2007 ). C-23 and C-24 hydroxyls, as in the case of agamenosides H ( 41 ) and I ( 35 ), shifts the C-22 signal to lower field by 2 — 4 ppm ( Eskander et al., 2010 ; Jin et al., 2004a ). Furostanol glycosides either have a free hydroxyl or a methoxyl group at C-22. The chemical shift of C-22 ranges from d 110.6 to 111.2 in the case of the former, and d 112.1 to 112.9 in the latter (Abdel-Gawad et al., 1999; Jin et al., 2004b ; Perez et al., 2014 ; Yokosuka et al., 2009; Yokosuka and Mimaki, 2007 , 2009).

4.1.3.1. Ring fusion type .
The fusion between the rings of the steroidal nucleus determines the orientation of the substituents present at the respective junctions. All steroidal sapogenins/saponins reported from
Agave
have a trans -fusion between rings B/C and C/D, and a cis -fusion between rings D/E. The A/B rings may have a cis- or trans- fusion and, therefore, structure elucidation of sapogenins/ saponins of
Agave
requires determination of the A/B ring junction. The trans- and cis- A/B fusions lead to a - and b -oriented 5-H, respectively. The 1 H and 13 C NMR chemical shifts of C/H-3, -5, -9 and -19 can be significantly influenced by the type of ring fusion (Agrawal, 2003; Agrawal et al., 1998). For example, an a -oriented H- 5 resonates at the d 0.78, and its corresponding carbon appears at d 44.6. However, the b -oriented 5-H is observed at d 2.02, with the C-5 appearing at 36.6.

2D-ROESY and NOESY are also used to ascertain the ring fusion type . ROE/NOE correlations between CH 3 -19/H-4 b , CH 3 -19/H-8, CH 3 -18/H-8 and CH 3 -18/H-20 confirm A/B trans , B/C trans C/D trans and D/E cis- fusions, respectively. Further , correlations between H-14/H-16 and -17 give evidence for cis -fused D/E rings ( Eskander et al., 2010 ; Perez et al., 2013 ; Yokosuka and Mimaki, 2007 ). In case of the aglycone of magueyoside C ( 70 ), the 19- CH 3 group correlated with H-2, H-4ax., H-1eq., H-8 and H-11 ax. Also , the 18- CH 3 correlated with H-8 and H-11ax. These ROESY correlations also indicated trans -fused A/B rings and b -oriented 18- and 19-methyls ( Perez et al., 2013 )
.

4.1.3.2. Stereochemistry at C-25. Steroidal sapogenins and saponins occur as 25 R- and 25 S- stereoisomers and are characterized by equatorial ( a -oriented) and axial ( b -oriented) 27-methyl groups, respectively. Agrawal (2003, 2004) has derived empirical rules based on 1 H NMR spectroscopic analysis for determination of 25 R- / 25 S- stereochemistry of these compounds. In the case of 25 S - compounds having a spirostanol skeleton, the geminal protons of ring F viz. H 2 -23, -24 and –26 are more resolved and the difference between the chemical shifts of the two protons is > 0.35 ppm. This difference, in 25 R -spirostanol glycosides, is usually < 0.20 ppm. For furostanol glycosides, the difference between the chemical shifts of the geminal H 2 -26 is < 0.48 for 25 R - and > 0.57 for 25 S- configuration (Agrawal, 2003, 2004). Table S1 shows chemical shifts of geminal protons of the ring F of steroidal sapogenins and saponins reported from
Agave
. It is noteworthy here that chemical shifts of H 2 -23 and H
2 -24 in
25 S -spirostanol glycosides are much more resolved as compared to 25 R -spirostanol glycosides. Chemical shifts of H 2 -26 show distinctive values that are conclusive of a 25 R / S -configuration. For example, in the case of 25 R -spirostanol glycosides, the difference between the chemical shifts of the H 2 -26 geminal protons ranges from 0.06 to 0.12 ppm. The same difference, in 25 S -spirostanol glycosides, is from 0.67 to 0.71 ppm. For furostanol glycosides, the chemical shift difference between the geminal H 2 -26 is
0.32 — 0.34 in
the 25 R - and 0.59 in the 25 S - configurations.

NOE and NOESY techniques are also used to determine the stereochemistry at position 25. In case of 39 , the R -configuration was deduced by the NOE correlation of 27-methyl with H-26 eq./ax. and H-24 ax. ( Yokosuka et al., 2000 ). Similarly, the correlation of H-25 with H-23ax. gave indication about the R -configuration in 40 ( Yokosuka and Mimaki, 2007 ).

4.1.3.3. Keto group. Several sapogenins and saponins of
Agave
have a keto group located at C-12. Neotigogenone ( 16 ) is an exception, with a keto group at C-3. The 12-CO absorption appears at d 212 to 214 and leads to a downfield shift (10 — 15 ppm) of the adjacent C-13. Location of the carbonyl at C-12 was confirmed by the analysis of the J -values of H 2 -11. These protons showed only one vicinal coupling with H-9 ( Perez et al., 2013 ). In the HMBC spectrum, H 3 -18 and H-17 showed a 3 J C-H cross peak with carbonyl carbon confirming its location at C-12 ( Eskander et al., 2010 ).

4.1.3.4. Unsaturation. Several unsaturated sapogenins and saponins have been reported from
Agave
. However, olefinic bonds are very typical, in that they are present at the position- 5 in the majority of cases ( 7 , 8 ,
22 — 24
,
69 — 72
,
92 — 95
,
99 — 102
,
127 — 128
, 130 ,
133 — 136
and 139 ). This double bond results in appearance of carbon resonances at d 139.5 to 141.2 (C-5) and 121.2 to 122.1 (C-6). Further, the presence of the double bond can be ascertained by a one proton signal at d 5.22 to 5.35 appearing as a broad singlet, doublet or multiplet. The 1 H and 13 C chemical shifts of this double bond are completely unaffected by hydroxyl substitutions in ring A ( Macias et al., 2007 ; Perez et al., 2013 ), 12-oxo group ( Perez et al., 2013 , 2014 ), glycosylation at C-10 (Abdel-Gawad et al., 1999) or even the type of sapogenin skeleton (i.e. furostan or spirostan) (Abdel-Gawad et al., 1999; Macias et al., 2010 ; Perez et al., 2014 ; Zou et al., 2006 ).

In the case of Δ 9(11) unsaturation ( 58 , 103 and 126 ), the olefinic proton (H-11) appears as a singlet or doublet at d 5.93 to 5.95. The two olefinic carbons appear at d 170 (C-9) and 120 (HC-11). The position of the double bond was confirmed by long-range HMBC correlations of H-11 with C-8, -10 and –13. It is noteworthy that Δ 9(11) in 103 led to a considerable downfield shift in H-8 ( d 2.36). A similar trend was observed in the chemical shifts of C- 8 in compounds 58 and 126 , where a downfield shift of 2 — 3 ppm was observed ( Perez et al., 2013 ; Yokosuka and Mimaki, 2009 ).

Saponins with a Δ 25(27) are relatively uncommon in
Agave
. However, compound 72 was isolated from leaves of
Agave decipiens
and it has a spirostan skeleton glycosylated at position 10. It also has two double bonds at Δ 5 and Δ 25(27) . The olefinic resonances at C-25 and -27 were identified by d 143.3 (C) and d 108.6 ( CH 2 ). The exocyclic methylene depicted by proton signals at d 4.81, 4.78 (H 2 - 27), along with corresponding carbon signals is characteristic of Δ 25(27) unsaturation (Abdel-Gawad et al., 1999). Fig. S4 shows the positions of the olefinic bonds as found in the saponins of
Agave
. The chemical shift ranges of the protons and carbons involved in the double bonds are also presented. 4.1.3.5. Hydroxyl substituents. Hydroxyl substituents are generally present at positions 2, 3 and 6 in saponins of
Agave
. In case of spirostanol glycosides, hydroxyl groups have also been encountered at C-23 and rarely at either C-12 ( 70 ) or C-20 ( 40 ). In furostanol glycosides of
Agave
, C-12, -20 and –23 hydroxyls have not been observed so far. However, a C-22 hydroxyl (or methoxyl) is invariably present.

The 3-OH is always b -oriented withorientation being ascertained by NOE interactions of H-3 with H-5. Since H-5 is axial, this interaction determines the axial orientation for H-3 and consequently a b -oriented 3-OH. In the case of agavegenin D ( 28 ), an a - orientation of H-3 and subsequently, b -orientation of 3-OH was ascertained by ROESY correlations of H-3 ( d 3.86) with H-1 a ( d 0.94), H-2 a ( d 2.04), H-4 a ( d 1.80) and H-5 ( d 1.07) ( Jin et al., 2004a ). In the presence of a free 3 b -OH, H-3 appears at d 3.74 to 4.11 and C-3 at d 67.1 to 71.1 (Agrawal et al., 1998; Jin et al., 2004a ). The 3 b -hydroxyl group is glycosidically bound in the majority of cases and glycosylation leads to a downfield shift of 3 — 8 ppm in C-3 ( Yokosuka and Mimaki, 2007 ). The effect of the type of A/B ring fusion on the chemical shifts of C/H-3 has already been discussed. A 2 a -OH brings about significant downfield shifts in C/H-1, C/H-2 and C-3. The chemical shift of H-3 remains unaffected though. Chemical shift ranges are d 1.22 to 1.55 (H-1ax.), 2.14 to 2.29 (H-1eq.), 3.92 to 4.06 (H-2), 43.4 to 45.7 (C-1), 69.7 to 72.7 (C-2) and 83.4 to 84.8 (C- 3) ( Jain, 1987 ; Macias et al., 2007 , 2010 ; Perez et al., 2013 ; Perez et al., 2014 ; Uniyal et al., 1991b ; Yokosuka and Mimaki, 2009 ). Three spirostanol glycosides with 2 b -OH have been reported from
Agave utahensis
. These compounds are characterized by a C-1 present at d 40.5, C-2 at d 66.8 — 67.1 and C-3 at d 79.7 to 81.7. The proton chemical shifts range from d 3.82 to 3.88 for H-2 and d 4.34 to 4.46 for H-3 (Yokosuka et al., 2009).

The positioning of an a -hydroxyl group at C-6 leads to appearance of C-5 at d 52.1 to 53.8, C-6 at d 68.3 to 71.3, C-7 at d 41.3 to 42.6 and C-9 at d 54.0 to 54.9. The proton chemical shifts for H-6 range from d 3.53 to 3.60 ( Ohtsuki et al., 2004 ; Silva et al., 2005 ; Yokosuka and Mimaki, 2007 ). Glycosylation of the 6-OH shifts C-6 further downfield to d 79.5 to 81.1 ( Jin et al., 2004a ; Monterrosas-Brisson et al., 2013 ; Yokosuka and Mimaki, 2007 ; Yokosuka et al., 2000 ; Yu et al., 2011 ). The orientation of 6-OH was confirmed as a by the NOE correlations of H-6 with CH 3 -19 and H-8 ( Yokosuka and Mimaki, 2007 ).

Owing to the basic skeleton, a hydroxyl moiety is present at C-22 ( d 110.6 to 111.2) in furostanol saponins ( Jin et al., 2004b ; Perez et al., 2014 ). In several cases, C-22 was methoxylated and characterized by d 112.1 to 112.9 (C-22) and d C 46.3 to 47.4 and d H 3.12 to 3.28 (OCH 3 ) (Abdel-Gawad et al., 1999; da Silva et al., 2002 ; Yokosuka et al., 2009; Yokosuka and Mimaki, 2007 ). Therefore, the 22-OCH 3 and 22-OH compounds can be distinguished on the basis of their 1 H and 13 C NMR spectroscopic data ( Agrawal et al., 1995 ). Also, a methoxy substitution at C-22 leads to a downfield shift (1 — 2 ppm) of C-22 and an upfield shift (7 ppm) in C-23 ( Macias et al., 2010 ). The orientation of the 22-OH/OCH 3 can be determined by NOE/ROE correlations between methoxy protons to H-16, -17 and –21 and these indicated an a -orientation for 22-OH/ OCH 3 and a 22 R configuration, respectively ( Macias et al., 2010 ; Yokosuka et al., 2009; Yokosuka and Mimaki, 2007 , 2009). Further, the 22 S configuration (agamenoside J, 116 ) was suggested from ROESY correlations of H-16 ( d 4.90) with H-14 ( d 1.04), H-15 a ( d 1.97), H-17 ( d 1.87) and H-O-22 ( d 5.93) ( Jin et al., 2004a ).

4.1.3.6. Sugar moieties. The complete identification of the sugar units present in saponins involves determination of 1) number and identification of sugars, 2) sequence of sugars and 3) linkage of sugar or sugar chain to the aglycone.

Glycosylation at particular position(s) of sapogenins brings about a downfield shift in the 1 H and 13 C NMR signals of the respective protons and carbons. For example, glycosylation of the 3-OH moiety in agavoside A ( 29 ) shifts the H/C-3 signals to d H 3.93 and d C 77.0. These signals in the aglycone (hecogenin, 1 ) appear at d H 3.44 and d C 70.7 (Jin et al., 2003). Similarly, in chlorogenin 6- O - b - D-glucopyranoside ( 31 ), glycosylation of the 6-OH brings about a downfield shift 11.1 ppm C-6 ( Mimaki et al., 1991 ). Further, the connection between the sapogenin and the sugar chain was established by the HMBC correlations between a) the anomeric proton and the carbons of the aglycone and b) protons of the aglycone and anomeric carbon of the sugar ( Perez et al., 2013 ; Yokosuka and Mimaki, 2007 , 2009). In the case of magueyoside A, a NOE correlation between anomeric proton of the first sugar and the H-3 of aglycone confirmed the placement of the oligosaccharide chain at C-3 ( Perez et al., 2013 ). In the case of furostanol glycosides, HMBC cross peak was observed between the anomeric proton of glucopyranosyl moiety and C-26 of the aglycone. Further, ROESY correlations between the anomeric proton and H 2 -26 confirmed the glycosylation position as C-26 ( Perez et al., 2014 ).

Anomeric proton and carbon resonances were observed in a well defined region ( d H 4.4 to 6.1 and d C 98 to 109). The broad singlets and doublets of anomeric protons were linked to their respective carbons on the basis of HMQC or HSQC correlations. These signals were then used to determine the number of monosaccharides present in a saponin molecule. A complete assignment of the glycosidic protons was achieved by 1 H- 1 H COSY, 1D-TOCSY and 1D-ROESY experiments. Further, HMQC or HSQC helped establish the C-H connectivity ( Chen et al., 2011 ; Eskander et al., 2010 ; Pant et al., 1994 ; Perez et al., 2014 ).

In 1D-TOCSY and 1D-ROESY techniques, the selective excitation of each anomeric proton revealed typical spin systems that can be assigned to a particular monosaccharide unit ( Chen et al., 2011 ; Macias et al., 2007 ; Perez et al., 2014 ). The b -D-glucopyranosyl moieties were characterized by doublet signals ( d 4.70 to 5.6, J ¼ 7.1 — 8.4 Hz) of anomeric protons and spin systems of axial H-1 to H-5 ( 3 J H-H > 7 Hz). The anomeric protons of 26- O -glucopyranosyl units in the furostanol type of saponins appeared at d 4.77 to 4.88 ( da Silva et al., 2002 ; da Silva and Parente, 2007 ; Eskander et al., 2010 ; Jin et al., 2004a ; Perez et al., 2014 ; Yokosuka et al., 2009; Yokosuka and Mimaki, 2007 , 2009; Yu et al., 2011 ; Zou et al., 2006 ).

The anomeric signals of b -D-galactopyranosyl unit appeared at d 4.76 — 4.94 (d, J ¼ 6.7 — 7.9 Hz) and the equatorial H-4 was observed as a fine doublet ( J H-3-H-4 ¼ 2.5 — 3.3 Hz). b -D-Xylopyranose had six coupled protons and the anomeric proton was present at d 5.06 to 5.74 (d, J ¼ 6.1 — 7.9 Hz). The a -L-rhamnopyranosyl unit had its anomeric protons at d 6.09 to 5.75 as a broad singlet or a doublet ( J ¼ 1.3 — 1.7 Hz). It was characterized by COSY correlations between CH 3 -6 and H-5 and the a -configuration was supported by the axialaxial relationship between H-3/H-4 and H-4/H-5 ( J> 9 Hz) and the axial-equatorial H-2/H-3 ( J < 5 Hz) ( da Silva et al., 2006 ; Macias et al., 2007 ; Ohtsuki et al., 2004 ; Yokosuka and Mimaki, 2007 ; Yu et al., 2011 ; Zou et al., 2006 ). The a -anomer of rhamnopyranose was also characterized by a 1D-ROESY correlation between the H-1 and H-2, while a cross-peak between H-3 and H-5 was absent ( Perez et al., 2014 ).

The linkage between monosaccharides of the sugar chain can be deduced from the 13 C NMR chemical shifts. Non-anomeric carbons involved in a glycosidic linkage show a substantial downfield shift in comparison to unsubstituted carbons. These ’glycosylation shifts’ are used to determine the points of linkages between two consecutive monosaccharides in an oligosaccharide unit of saponins. The terminal monosaccharide can be indicated by the absence of any glycosylation shift. Table S2 summarises glycosylation shifts of various b -D-glucopyranosyl moieties commonly found in saponins of
Agave
. Although these data are not exhaustive, and are based on a small number of examples, they indicate the patterns of downfield shifts in 13 C NMR signals of carbons involved in glycosidic bonds. Final assignments of the protons and carbons in the oligosaccharide unit were based on the correlations in HSQC and HSQC-TOCSY spectra. The sequence of sugar chains was established by HMBC/ROESY experiments.

As the number of sugars and branching points increase, the NMR spectra of saponins become more complicated. Acid hydrolysis has been widely used for identification of monosaccharide components of saponins of
Agave
. A typical acid hydrolysis protocol involves refluxing the saponin in the presence of 1 M HCl-methanol ( Pant et al., 1994 ) or 1 M sulfuric acid in 50% ethanol for 3 — 4 h. The reaction mixture is diluted with water to yield the (crystalline) aglycone which precipitates, while the monosaccharides remain in solution ( Yi et al., 1989 ). The identity, absolute configuration and numbers of monosaccharides were established by various chromatographic methods ( Table S3 ).

The type of glycosidic linkage between the monosaccharides of the sugar chain of saponins was determined by methylation analysis. Saponins are methylated using a) dimethyl sulfoxide/lithium methylsulfinyl carbanion/methyl iodide (Hakomori’ s method) ( da Silva and Parente, 2007 ) or b) sodium hydride/methyl iodide in hexamethylphoshoric triamide (HPMA) or dimethyl sulfoxide (DMSO) ( Uniyal et al., 1990 ). The permethylated products were hydrolyzed using hydrochloric acid, perchloric acid or trifluoroacetic acid. Individual methylated monosaccharides were identified by a) GLC or NMR of isolated compounds ( Varshney et al., 1982 ) b) paper chromatography ( Uniyal et al., 1991a ) or c) analyzed as partial alditol acetates by GC-MS ( da Silva and Parente, 2007 ). Fig. S5 shows the partial alditol acetates formed from the sugar moiety of saponin 129 .

Agave plants
have been used for their medicinal properties since times immemorial. Most ethnopharmacological uses of these plants can be attributed to their antimicrobial and antioxidant activities ( Ahumada-Santos et al., 2013 ; Santos-Zea et al., 2012 ). These plants are used in the treatment of gastrointestinal and urological disorders, dysentery, wound infections, cancer, hypertension and diabetes ( Cornara et al., 2009 ; Duncan et al., 1999 ; Semenya et al., 2012 ). Some biological activities of
Agave
compounds (and extracts) are scientifically proven and mechanistically studied with the help of various in vitro and in vivo assays and models ( da Silva and Parente, 2007 ; Hamed et al., 2006 ; Perez et al., 2014 ; Quintans et al., 2014 ; Yokosuka et al., 2009). These activities are of medicinal and pharmacological significance or of agricultural importance.

By virtue of their capacity to alter membrane permeability, saponins have powerful hemolytic activity ( Baumann et al., 2000 ; Sparg et al., 2004 ). These compounds have an amphipathic (bipolar) structure with a hydrophobic sapogenin and a hydrophilic sugar moiety and have an affinity for sterols on membranes of erythrocytes ( Sparg et al., 2004 ). The hemolytic effects of spirostanol ( 110 ) and furostanol ( 129 ) glycosides having the same sugar chain at C-3 of the sapogenin were evaluated. Compound 129 demonstrated a complete absence of hemolytic effects, while compound 110 caused significant hemolysis in an erythrocyte suspension. Therefore, it was inferred that since 129 is a bidesmosidic saponin and the sugar moieties were distantly placed in the structure (at C-3 and C-26), it reduced the overall hydrophobicity of the compound. Hence, loss of amphipathic character led to loss of activity ( da Silva and Parente, 2007 ). These results were further verified by absence of hemolytic effects in the compounds 132 and 140 ( da Silva et al., 2002 ; da Silva and Parente, 2005 ).

Conventionally, the brine shrimp (
Artemia salina
) lethality assay has been used to study the cytotoxicity of natural compounds and extracts ( Krishnaraju et al., 2005 ). The ethanolic and aqueous extracts of the leaves of
Agave cantala
were tested for their lethality against brine shrimps. The 50% lethal concentration (LC 50 ) of the alcoholic and aqueous extracts was 12.5 and 15.0 mg/mL, respectively ( Ramachandran et al., 2011 ). In the same assay, the LC 50 of the aqueous extract of the leaves of
Agave intermixta
L. was 345.22 mg / mL. The aqueous extract of
A. intermixta
L. was further evaluated for its antimitotic activity in
Allium cepa
root meristematic cells. A complete inhibition of the cell division was observed after 24 h treatment. However, no chromosomal abnormalities were observed in the cells. This extract also exhibited a cytostatic activity on HEp-2 cells with an IC 50 of 68.0 µ g/mL ( Saenz et al., 2000 ). The methanol extract of the leaves of
A. americana
showed an IC 50 of 826.1 µ g/mL against Human MCF-7 breast carcinoma cells and an IC 50 of 8.455 µ g/mL against VERO (African green monkey kidney cell line) in MTT assay ( Anajwala et al., 2010 ).

Cytotoxicity of saponins isolated from
A. utahensis
was evaluated using HL-60 human promyelocytic leukemia cells. Compounds 41 and 54 exhibited cytotoxicity with an IC 50 of 4.9 µ g/mL. The C-2 hydroxyl and C-12 carbonyl moieties reduced the cytotoxicity of these compounds (Yokosuka et al., 2009; Yokosuka and Mimaki, 2009 ). These compounds mediated cell death by apoptosis. Caspase-3 was found to be activated when HL-60 cells were treated with 41 and 54 (20 µ g/mL for 6 h) (Yokosuka et al., 2009).

Results of cytotoxicity studies of the compounds isolated from the methanolic extract of
A. sisalana
leaves implied that the sugar moiety plays a crucial role in bioactivity of saponins. Saponins ( 66 , 104 , 105 and 137 ) are more cytotoxic as compared to the sapogenins ( 1 , 2 , 13 , 14 and 20 ) ( Chen et al., 2011 ). The sequence and number of the sugar units present in the sugar chain of the saponin also affected cytotoxicity. The diglycosides ( 36 and 37 ) were less cytotoxic, as compared to the hexasaccharides (
107 — 109
) ( Ohtsuki et al., 2004 ).

Mouse ear edema model (edema induction by 12- O - tetradecanoylphorbol-13-acetate, TPA) was used to evaluate the antiinflammatory potential of the acetone extract of the leaves of
Agave tequilana
,
A. americana
and
Agave angustifolia ( Monterrosas-Brisson et al., 2013 )
. The extract of
A. americana
showed maximum activity with 81% inhibition of auricular edema at a dose of 6 mg / ear. Cantalasaponin-1 ( 39 ) was purified from the extract of
A. americana
by a bioassay-guided fractionation and was tested for its antiinflammatory activity. It showed a 90% inhibition of ear edema at a dose of 2.0 mg per ear ( Monterrosas-Brisson et al., 2013 ). Hecogenin ( 1 ) also showed antiinflammatory activity in carrageenin-induced paw edema model ( Peana et al., 1997 ). Acute inflammatory model of topical edema on mouse ear skin (induction by application of croton oil) was also used to evaluate the antiinflammatory potential of saponins ( da Silva and Parente, 2007 ). A comparison of the antiinflammatory activity of spirostanol ( 110 ) and furostanol ( 129 ) glycosides revealed that 110 suppressed the edema significantly and the activity was comparable to the reference drugs (indomethacin and dexamethasone). These results pointed toward the involvement of rings E and F of the spirostane nucleus in the bioactivity ( da Silva and Parente, 2007 ) which used the capillary permeability assay for the evaluation of antiinflammatory activity ( Fig. 2 ). Compound 140 also showed a signifi- cant inhibition of an acetic acid-induced increase in capillary permeability ( da Silva and Parente, 2005 ).

Hecogenin ( 1 ), a steroidal sapogenin with a spectrum of pharmacological activities, is perhaps the most studied sapogenin of
Agave
. It is an important precursor of steroid hormones ( Quintans et al., 2014 ). Hecogenin acetate ( 1a ) exhibited considerable antihyperalgesic activity in case of hyperalgesia induced in mice by carrageenan, TNF- a , dopamine and PGE 2 . It reduced levels of proinflammatory cytokines, such as IL-1 b , and inhibited Fos-like expression in the spinal cord ( Quintans et al., 2014 ). Another study reported the antinociceptive activity of 1a and evaluated the involvement of periaqueductal gray in the antinociception mechanism. The systemic administration of 1a to male Swiss Webster mice increased Fos expression in the periaqueductal gray and thereby produced antinociception mediated by opioid receptors and by activation of descending pain-inhibitory pathways ( Gama et al., 2013 ).

Hecogenin ( 1 ) exhibited a gastroprotective effect in ethanol-and indomethacin-induced gastric ulcer models of Swiss mice. It decreased lipid peroxidation and nitrite levels and increased COX-2 expression. The effect of hecogenin ( 1 ) was attributed to opening of K þ ATP channels and prostaglandin synthesis. It also showed antiinflammatory activity by decreasing release of myeloperoxidase from human neutrophils in vitro ( Cerqueira et al., 2012 ).

Ahumada-Santos et al. (2013) have investigated the antioxidant activity of six
Agave species
growing in Mexico . The wild species included
A. rzedowskiana
,
A. impressa
,
A. ornithobroma
and
A. schidigera
and the cultivated species was
A. tequilana
.
A. rzedowskiana
showed the highest antioxidant activity (27.41 µ M of Trolox equivalents per gram of dry weight) in DPPH assay ( Ahumada-Santos et al., 2013 ). Ethanolic extract of leaves of
A. sisalana
showed a weak inhibition of xanthine oxidase, tyrosinase and lipoxygenase ( Chen et al., 2009 ).

Antimicrobial activity of crude extracts of different
Agave species
was done using disc-diffusion or well-diffusion methods ( Hammuel et al., 2011 ; Rizwan et al., 2012 ; Santos et al., 2009 ; Verastegui et al., 2008 ). The saponin-rich methanol and aqueous extracts of
A. sisalana
were evaluated for their antimicrobial potential. The minimum inhibitory concentration (MIC) of both extracts against
Staphylococcus aureus
,
Salmonella typhi
,
Escherichia coli
,
Streptococcus pyogenes
and
Candida albicans
ranged from 10 to 20 mg /mL ( Hammuel et al., 2011 ). The methanol extract of the leaves of
Agave attenuata
showed a strong inhibitory activity against
Aspergillus fl avus
and
Alternaria alternata
with MIC values of 18.4 and 69.4 mg /mL, respectively. The chloroform fraction of this extract also showed strong inhibition of
Rhizoctonia solani
and
A. fl avus
with MIC of 20.4 and 25.1 mg /mL, respectively. The n - butanol fraction of the same extract inhibited
Escherichia coli
with an MIC of 15.2 mg /mL ( Rizwan et al., 2012 ).

Ethanolic extracts of the leaves of
Agave lecheguilla
,
A. picta
,
A. scabra
and
A. lophantha
were tested for their antimicrobial activity against several bacterial (
E. coli
,
S. aureus
,
Listeria monocytogenes
,
Vibrio cholerae
,
Bacillus cereus
and
Yersinia enterocolitica
) and fungal (
Cryptococcus neoformans
,
Microsporum gypseum
,
Trichophyton tonsurans
and
Sporotrix schenckii
) species. In the antibacterial assay, the extract of
A. picta
inhibited growth of
E. coli
,
S. aureus L. monocytogenes
and
V. cholera
significantly. However, the other extracts were not active. All four
Agave
extracts were active against the tested fungal species ( Verastegui et al., 2008 ). Similar studies established the antimicrobial potential of extracts of
A. lecheguilla
,
A. rzedowskiana
,
A. impressa
,
A. ornithobroma
,
A. schidigera
,
A. tequilana
and
A. sisalana
( Ahumada-Santos et al., 2013 ; Santos et al., 2009 ; Verastegui et al., 1996 ).

Yang et al. (2006) have also evaluated the antifungal activity of 28 steroidal compounds, including 6 sapogenins and 12 saponins reported from
Agave species.
The results of this study revealed that all the sapogenins were inactive up to a concentration of 20 µ g/mL. Amongst the saponins, the compounds 96 and 98 (with tigogenin ( 13 ) as aglycone) () showed significant activity against
C. neoformans
. Antifungal activity was associated with individual aglycones, as well as the composition of the sugar chains ( Yang et al., 2006 ).

The antifungal efficacy of
Agave plants
was also evaluated against the fungal pathogens of crops. The methanolic leaf extract of
A. americana
showed antifungal activity against
Alternaria brassicae
and inhibited conidial germination of the fungus ( Guleria and Kumar, 2009 ). Similarly, aqueous extracts of bulbs of
A. lechuguilla
inhibited
Fusarium oxysporum
, a fungal pathogen of tomato ( de Rodriguez et al., 2006 ).

The ethanol-water (7:3) extract of
Agave offoyana
leaves was evaluated for its phytotoxic potential. The standard target species included
Lactuca sativa
L.,
Lycopersicum esculentum
L.,
Lepidium sativum
L. and
Allium cepa L. Some
sub-fractions of the ethanol-water extract inhibited the root growth of target species signifi- cantly and were more active as compared to Logran ® , a commercial herbicide. Phytotoxicity assessment of pure compounds revealed that the sugar chain at C-3 of the sapogenin (aglycone) affected the bioactivity. Compound with five sugar units ( 101 ) had a better inhibition profile, as compared to the compound with four sugar units ( 71 ). Also, b -D-xylopyranosyl moiety (instead of OE -L-rhamnopyranosyl) at the end of the glycosidic chain increased the phytotoxicity slightly (as shown by comparison of compounds 93 , IC 50 101.4 µ M) and 100 , IC 50 90.4 µ M). No difference in activity was found between the spirostane- and furostane-type of the sapogenin nucleus ( Perez et al., 2013 , 2014 ).

The crude ethanolic extract of
A. cantala
was lethal against
Biomphalaria glabrata
(vector of schistosomiasis) at a concentration of 25 ppm and compound 77 purified from this extract showed activity at 10 ppm over 24 h ( Rana, 1993 ). The ethanolic extracts of the fresh leaves of
A. attenuata
and
A. sisalana
were tested for their molluscicidal activity against
Biomphlaria alexandrina
. The LC 50 for both extracts after 72 h was 82 and 101 mg /L, respectively. A notable increase in the glutathione, glutathione peroxidase, glutathione reductase, glutathione S -transferase, catalase and Υ -glutamyl transferase was observed in snails exposed to high concentrations of
A. attenuata
extract. These enzymes were concluded to be responsible for protection of the snail in the presence of molluscicidal agents ( Hamed et al., 2006 ).

heading.emphasis: 6. Conclusion and future areas of research

subSection.paragraph:
The present review gave a summary of the saponins of
Agave
, their extraction, isolation and profiling methods, structure elucidation strategies and biological activities. The first and second sections of this article gave an overview of
Agave
and the saponins reported from this genus.

Agave
contains, primarily, steroidal sapogenins and saponins (
Tables 1 — 3
). Of the four known skeletons of steroidal saponins, two viz. spirostanols and furostanols are abundantly found in
Agave
(
Figs. 2 — 8
). Saponins having carboxylic moieties in the algycone and sugar(s) are not found in this genus.
Agave
saponins have typical glycosylation pattern with b -D-galactopyranose as the sugar directly attached to the aglycone in majority of the cases (
Figs. 3 — 8
). a -L-Rhamnopyranose is not observed in the saponins with one and two sugars. It is present in higher saccharides (
Figs. 6 — 7
); however, it is never linked directly to the aglycone moiety ( Uniyal et al., 1991a and 1991b ; da Silva and Parente, 2007 ).

Steroidal saponins constitute a group of compounds with varied structural and biological properties. The biological significance of these compounds calls for the need of elaboration of suitable extraction methods and isolation strategies. The third section of this article presented an up-to-date review of the methods of extraction, isolation and chemical profiling of the
Agave
saponins. The developments in the methods of extraction and chemical profiling of
Agave
saponins are rather slow. Classical methods viz. Soxhlet extraction and maceration were used in majority of the cases. However, other less time-consuming and greener methods such as ultra-sound assisted extraction, microwave-assisted extraction, super-critical fluid extraction and accelerated solvent extraction could increase the overall efficiency of the extraction procedures ( Majinda, 2012 ). Similarly, modern methods of analysis such as LC-MS and other hyphenated techniques may be of use in the analysis and structure elucidation of these compounds ( Sarkar and Nahar, 2006 ).

The section on structure elucidation described spectroscopic, as well as chemical methods. Chemical methods have been superseded by the spectroscopic techniques, such as 2D-NMR and highresolution mass spectroscopy. However, hydrolysis and methylation techniques are still used for of complex saponins. NMR methods were also employed to establish the overall structure, as well as the stereochemistries of
Agave
saponins. With the advent of solvent suppression tools, such as DOSY, it is now possible to determine saponin structures in mixtures ( Macias et al., 2010 ).

Various biological and pharmacological activities of
Agave plants
and their products have also been summarized. A number of bioactivities were attributed to saponins of
Agave
( Tables 2 and 3 ). The long history of human use, favorable pharmacodynamic and pharmacokinetic profiles and varied spectrum of bio-activities make
Agave
products attractive and safe candidates for therapeutic use ( Hackman et al., 2006 ). Substantial progress in the bioactivity evaluation and establishment of mechanisms of action of the isolated
Agave
compounds ( Tables 2 and 3 ) has paved the way for new product development. Currently, there is a shift from a single to a multiple target approach in drug discovery ( Medina-Franco et al., 2013 ). Future studies need to have a focus on structure activity relationships (SAR) of pure bioactive molecules of
Agave
isolated for strategic drug discovery leads and translational research for clinical applications ( Fishburn, 2013 ). Molecular modeling studies may also prove helpful in the preliminary evaluation and establishment of SAR ( Ali et al., 2012 ). A vast reservoir of
Agave spp.
remains untapped in terms of Phytochemistry, as well as pharmacology, and this is an area for future studies.

We acknowledge the financial support from Council of Industrial and Scientific Research (CSIR), Govt. of India (Grant No. 21(0961)/13/EMR-II). We also thank Director, CSIR-IHBT, Palampur, for support. CSIR-IHBT communication number for this article is 3867.
Supplementary data related to this article can be found at http:// dx.doi.org/10.1016/j.phytochem.2016.06.010.

document.paragraph: Dr. Jasmeen Sidana is a post-doctoral researcher at the CSIR-Institute of Himalayan Bioresource Technology, Palampur, India . She received her B. Pharm. from Punjabi University, Patiala, India . She earned her M.S. (Pharmacy) and Ph.D. in Natural Products from the National Institute of Pharmaceutical Education and Research (NIPER), SAS Nagar, Punjab , India . At NIPER, she studied the isolation, structure elucidation and chemo-profiling of natural products with special reference to formylated phloroglucinols. Her present research focuses on chemical profiling and bioactivity of saponin-bearing plants of the western Himalayas.
Dr. Om Sharma is Emeritus Scientist at CSIR - Institute of Himalayan Bioresource Technology, Palampur, India . Dr.

Sharma earned his PhD in Biochemistry at Central Drug Research Institute, Lucknow, India . Thereafter, he joined Agricultural Research Service and has served in different capacities in IVRI since 1977. Dr. Sharma has an experience of 41 years in research and teaching and has published 1126 research papers and review articles. He has won Commonwealth Postdoctoral fellowship at the University of West London, Brunel (1984 — 1985); Gold Medal of Panjab University, Chandigarh ; Best Paper Awards of the Society of Biological Chemists ( India ) on two occasions and of the Society of Toxicology ( India ). Dr. Sharma is a Fellow of the Society of Toxicology ( India ), is a life member of Indian Science Congress Association, Society of Biological Chemists, and Society of Toxicology. Dr. Sharma has worked extensively and published in the areas of free radical biochemistry, plant toxins, plant secondary metabolites, and natural products in relation to animal toxicity (biochemistry, disposition, mechanisms). The current focus of his research is modulation of rumen function using plant secondary metabolites and isolation, profiling and biological activity evaluation of plant saponins.

Dr. Bikram Singh has completed his Ph.D at CIMAP (1982 — 1987). After completion of his doctoral studies, he joined CSIR-IHBT on 1988 as Junior Scientist. During his tenure, he has visited Hannover, Germany under CSIR- DAAD, Bilateral Exchange and Rothamsted International, U.K. He has worked on the isolation and characterization of biologically important natural products and developed several analytical methods for their quantification. Presently, he is appointed as Senior Principal Scientist at CSIR-IHBT, Palampur, India and is working on the value addition of naturally occurring molecules along with the development of new catalytic methodologies for important transformations by using metal phthalocyanine as catalyst. He has 137 publications and nine patents to his credit. He has guided eight PhD students, two MPhil and fifteen MSc students. Presently eight students are doing PhD under his guidance.
